conclusion: Analyzing particle motion using the reciprocal velocity graph.
Plan to analyze step-by-step to determine whether the particle is accelerating or decelerating.
The graph shows 1/v on the y-axis versus displacement x on the x-axis.
The graph shows a straight line with positive slope going through the origin.
Since 1/v increases with x, v decreases as x increases.
Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with time: a = dv/dt.
If v is decreasing as x increases and v > 0, then dv/dt < 0.
A negative acceleration while moving in the positive direction means the particle is slowing down.
From the graph, 1/v ∝ x, which means v ∝ 1/x. As x increases, v decreases, confirming the particle is slowing down.
Reciprocal of velocity (1/v) increases linearly with displacement, meaning the velocity decreases as the particle moves further along its path.
Since a decreasing positive velocity corresponds to a negative acceleration, the particle is decelerating.
